['Hemoglobin - A protein found in red blood cells, which monkeys (like humans) have to transport oxygen throughout their body.', 'Chromosomes - Structures within cells, including those of monkeys, that contain genetic information and are involved in determining blood factors such as blood type.', 'Plasma - The liquid component of blood found in the veins of monkeys and humans alike, which carries various proteins, electrolytes, hormones, and waste products.', 'Leukocytes (White Blood Cells) - Immune cells present in the blood that help fight infections and diseases in monkeys as well as other animals.', "Erythrocytes (Red Blood Cells) - The red cell lineage, which is responsible for transporting oxygen to body tissues; an essential component of a monkey's blood.", 'Hematocrit - A measure of the percentage of red blood cells in the total volume of blood, indicative of how efficiently the circulatory system functions in primates like monkeys.', "Platelets (Thrombocytes) - Small cell fragments involved in clot formation; an integral part of a monkey's blood coagulation process.", 'Albumin - A protein found in plasma, which helps maintain proper fluid balance and transports various substances including hormones in monkeys.', 'Fibrinogen - An essential glycoprotein involved in the clotting of blood; monkeys share this factor with other mammals for wound healing and tissue repair.', "Globulins - A group of proteins within plasma, including antibodies that are part of the immune system; a critical aspect of a primate's defense mechanism.", 'Factor VIII - One of several blood clotting factors in monkeys and humans; essential for normal coagulation processes.', "Fibrin Degradation Products (FDPs) - Byproducts produced when fibrin, a key protein involved in blood clots, is broken down during the healing process; found in monkey's plasma as well.", 'Monocytes - A type of white blood cell that forms from stem cells and differentiates into macrophages or dendritic cells to help fight infections in primates like monkeys.', "Hormones - Chemical messengers found in a monkey's blood that regulate various bodily functions, including metabolism and reproduction.", "Cytokines - Signaling proteins involved in immune responses; their presence helps coordinate the body's defense against pathogens in both humans and primates like monkeys.", "Blood Typing Antigens (ABO) - Specific markers found on red blood cells that determine a monkey's blood type, as well as humans'.", 'Rh Factor - A protein found on the surface of red blood cells in both monkeys and humans; it determines positive or negative blood types based on whether this protein is present.', 'Hemophilia Factors (FVIII/IX) - Rare genetic disorders that affect clotting in primates, including monkeys; the absence of these factors can lead to excessive bleeding following injuries.', 'Thrombocytopenia - A condition characterized by a low number of platelets in the blood; it impairs proper clot formation and may result from diseases or medications affecting monkeys as well as humans.', 'Hemophilia Factors (FVIII/IX) - Rare genetic disorders that impact coagulation processes in primates, including both monkeys and humans; these deficienenas can lead to prolonged bleeding following trauma or surgery.']

["**Spot** - A distinct mark or stain on something, often used when referring to animals' fur patterns.", '**Discovery** - The act of finding something for the first time, which may involve spotting it unexpectedly.', '**Observation** - Noticing or perceiving something; in a scientific context, this often involves seeing phenomena with keen attention to detail.', "**Identification** - Recognizing and confirming an object's identity based on specific characteristics such as spots or marks.", '**Surveillance** - The careful watching of places, people, or situations; this can involve spotting unusual activity.', '**Sightseeing** - Visiting interesting places to see and appreciate the sights, which may include spotting notable landmarks.', '**Inspection** - A close examination, often for quality control purposes; inspectors are adept at noticing small details like spots or marks.', '**Scouting** - The act of searching carefully and thoroughly to find something; scouts may spot important landmarks during explorations.', "**Marksmanship** - A shooter's skill in hitting a target, which includes noticing the exact spot where the bullet lands on the target.", '**Hawk-eyed** - Having keen or sharp eyesight; someone who is particularly good at noticing details like spots.', '**Glimpsing** - Seeing something briefly and often unexpectedly, akin to spotting a fleeting moment.', '**Pinpointing** - Identifying the exact location or position of something with great precision; in this case, it could relate to identifying a single dot among many.', '**Bingo-spotter** - Someone who can quickly identify specific items (like numbers on cards) much like finding a "bingo spot."', '**Flashpoint** - A point at which something, especially an event or situation, becomes significantly intense; metaphorically speaking, it could be seen as the moment one notices a crucial detail that changes everything.', '**Motley** (as in a motley crew) – Describing a group of people with varied and unattractive appearances or characteristics; often used figuratively to describe an assortment that includes spotted individuals.', '**Kaleidoscope** - An optical instrument consisting of mirrors, lenses, etc., containing pieces of colored glass or paper, whose reflection produces changing patterns when viewed in rotation; a metaphor for seeing the world with multifaceted perspectives that might include noticing "spots" within broader contexts.', '**Rustic** - Pertaining to an old-fashioned or countryside style, often implying natural and unrefined qualities; rustic furniture may have spotted finishes due to age and wear.', '**Tessellation** - A tiling with no overlaps or gaps using one or more geometric shapes of equal size; this concept can apply in pattern recognition, including identifying a repeating "spot" design within larger patterns.']

['Marine Chronometer - A precise timekeeping device crucial to navigation, often found aboard clippers like those housed in Greenwich.', 'Sextant - An instrument used for measuring angular distances between objects; navigators on clippers would frequently use it.', 'Telescope - Clipper captains might have peered through telescopes, although primarily for celestial navigation rather than observation of preserved specimens.', "Log Book - A detailed record-keeping ledger where a captain documented the voyage; preserved items may highlight the paths taken by clipper ships like those in Greenwich collections.', "Spyglasses (Telescopic Sight) - For long-range visibility, an integral part of a ship's navigational equipment during its time.", 'Flagship - A term referring to the leading or most important vessel in a fleet; preserved clippers may have served as flagships at some point.', 'Hull Decoration - Clipper ships were known for their elaborate and decorative hull designs, which are often preserved and displayed.', "Captain's Quarters Furnishings - The personal items of a clipper ship’s captain may be preserved to give insight into maritime life at the time.", 'Ship Ballast - Material used to stabilize ships; examples might be showcased in museums, providing insights into cargo and usage aboard clippers like those found in Greenwich.', 'Chronometer Cradle - A cradle-like device for protecting marine chronometers during sea voyages, possibly displayed with preserved clipper ships at historic sites.', 'Seamanship Tools - Items such as ropes and knots; tools used by the crew of a clipper would be well-preserved examples in museums.', "Naval Ensign - A national flag flown from naval vessels, which might be on display alongside preserved clippers at institutions like Greenwich's maritime heritage sites.", 'Nautical Instruments - Comprehensive categories of nautical tools including, but not limited to, barometers, wind gauges, thermometers, which are often preserved on historical clipper ships and can be found in maritime museums like those at Greenwich.']

['Hyperbole - an exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally.', 'Overstatement - making something seem more significant than it is in reality.', 'Inflation - increasing prices or costs beyond their actual value, often used metaphorically.', 'Exaggeration - the act of representing something as being larger, better, worse, etc., than it really is.', 'Melodrama - a literary, dramatic, or cinematic work that treats unnatural situations as though they were realistic and serious.', 'Far-fetched - unlikely but possible; having little chance of happening in reality.', 'Fabrication - the act of making up stories or information with no basis in truth.', 'Exaggerated Fear - an irrational, excessive fear that is not based on factual evidence.', 'Puffery - exaggerated or false praise used to promote a product or service.', 'Sensationalism - the use of exciting or shocking stories at the expense of accuracy in order to provoke public interest and discussion.', "Grandiosity - an attitude marked by an excessively high opinion of one's own importance, abilities, achievements, etc.", 'Exaggerated Compliments - compliments that are too extravayer for the situation or person receiving them.', 'Magnification - making something seem larger, more important, or more significant than it really is.', 'Over-the-top - excessively dramatic or exaggerated in a way that seems ridiculous or unrealistic.', 'Unfounded Allegation - an accusation made without any basis for its truth.', 'Exaggerated Claim - making a statement more impressive, important, serious, etc., than it really is.', 'Melodramatic Behavior - displaying excessively emotional or exaggerated behavior that seems unrealistic or theatrical.', 'Inflatable Personality - an overly confident and self-important person who displays a high level of narcissism.', 'Exaggerated Narrative - a story or account with added details, events or descriptions to make it more exciting than reality.', 'Melodramatic Expression - displaying exaggerated emotions in an overly dramatic way that is not genuine or true to the situation.']
